author: 8BrickMario
title: Was it a wise purchase? Or should I go back in time and undo it?
review:
The first pack to represent Back to the Future in Dimensions, many were drawn to the pieces within, and the content it offered. Is it worth the hefty price?

Box/Instructions

The packaging is nice, and stands out among others in the toys-to-life aisle in stores. 

Parts

There are some pretty nice parts here, but the big one is the hoverboard. It's a completely new mold, essentially like the regular skateboard, but without axles and one of the ends being turned up and flat. The printing on the board looks great, and it's nice that we got it here. The NFC base for Marty is decorated with the colors of his shirt and vest and a stylized BttF render of his name. 

Minifigures

Marty McFly here is not a new figure, but he's still nice to have, as I don't own the Ideas DeLorean. He accurately represents the character, and he comes with his guitar, which, while needing some printing, is a nice addition. 

The build

The build was pretty easy, but some nice techniques were used for the DeLorean.

The completed model

The builds here are pretty good, with the glorified stand for the hoverboard being a bit pointless for the first version of the build, but the DeLorean really stands out. It's nicely detailed and looks like the car, but the very best part is that they made the doors open just like they do on the actual car! Such a great little detail. 

Gameplay

I will echo the statements that the level here is a bit underwhelming. It's basically a straight retelling of the first film, with 70% of the plot removed. The whole issue of Marty altering his family history and jeopardizing his future is never touched on, with him arriving in 1955 and immediately jumping to the night where he travels back. I did like how they changed the circumstances and solution to Doc's death, but the level felt uninspired and lacking in enough content. 

Marty as a character is fairly useful, with the main draw being the guitar's use for shattering glass LEGO with its noise. 

The hoverboard is also pretty nice, with its ability to glide over gaps and eventually be upgraded to full flight. 

The biggest thing here is the DeLorean, with its unique ability to use time-travel treadmills to enter different time periods, similarly to the TARDIS. These treadmills appear in levels and adventure worlds, and usually lead to important collectibles.

The Adventure World is probably the most involved of the bunch, with the bulk of its puzzle-solving revolving around traveling between Western Hill Valley, present-day Hill Valley, and futuristic Hill Valley to unlock things between the different time periods. It's pretty fun, although the amount of time travel involved can be a bit annoying. 

Overall opinion

While this is one of the weaker Level Packs, I think it's still a good purchase. It unlocks a fun, puzzle-filled world and an important vehicle to the game, and sometimes a short level can be nice. Maybe wait for a sale, but get it eventually.

author: BlueStation
title: "This is heavy..."
review:
The initial appeal of Lego Dimensions for me personally was the chance to collect some unique minifigures which in some cases I couldn't get anywhere else. I stayed away from the core Lego Dimensions game for quite a while, choosing instead to only pick up supplementary packs if they had that collectible appeal at the right discount.

The Back to the Future level pack was one of the first packs I picked up, and while I didn't pay the full retail of $29.99 USD, I ponied up a little more than I otherwise would have. I missed out on the Delorean and Dimensions was a welcome opportunity to add Marty and Doc to my collection (I would later MOC a DeLorean for them) - BTTF was a favorite of mine growing up.

When I finally did start up the proper game, this was the first level pack I attempted after finishing the main story. How does it stack up?

Parts

One of the most collectable aspects of this pack was the inclusion of Marty's Hoverboard, an element & design never seen in LEGO before. In the game, it functions as an additional vehicle for players to use, but as part of the physical pack it adds one more reason for fans to add this to their collection as the board was not included in 21103. It's a great piece - perfect LEGO re-creation of the board from the movie, and can be held by a minifigure as well as "ridden."

Marty is also given a guitar which is disappointingly not printed, unlike the one found in 2015's Monster Rocker.

The remaining elements are pretty unremarkable, even extraneous in the case of the Hoverboard "build." But the other parts are not the main draw of the pack.

Minifigure

This Marty McFly minifigure appears to be the same version as from the DeLorean set - and it remains outstanding. It looks just like Michael J. Fox from the movie, as much as any LEGO minifigure could. The detail right on down to the half-buttoned shirt under the printed vest - it's all there. Marty has a smirk expression and a concerned expression on the two-sided head piece. Even the color of the pants is accurate.

Marty is given a printed toy-tag base with his name in the BTTF signature font.

Gameplay

And this is where our review takes a bit of a turn. For me, this pack already had value as a way to finally add Marty to my collection, along with his hoverboard. When I finally got the game, however, I was a little disappointed in the digital results.

This pack exclusively gives you the Back to the Future Level content. The level covers the plot of the first film only (which is the first missed opportunity, though it's arguable that covering all three films would have exceeded the limits of the Level Pack size).

The stages in the level, while fun, do not feel progressive in the story of the movie. What I mean is that, for example - the Sedgewick Hotel stage in the Ghostbusters Level Pack actually feels like you are playing through that part of the story (in it's own way), tracking down and catching Slimer. Until the end of the BTTF Level Pack, the stages mostly feel like you are exploring an area that exists frozen in a moment of the movie - Marty at Doc's House in the intro; Marty escaping the barn right after going back in time, etc. And the story skips very quickly to the finale with the clock tower. This makes sense in remembering the movie - the bulk of it was abut Marty interacting with his parents - but LEGO and TT often find creative ways to repurpose or rearrange the gameplay and content to become more playable. Here, it feels lacking.

The final stage where you power up the clock tower does provide a bit of fun, and (if you have the right character abilities available) even has a hidden area re-creating the school dance setting. These are the fun kind of inclusions that populate most of the Level Packs and Adventure Worlds and I wish BTTF had more of them.

This was one of the first Level Packs released with the Dimensions game (and was heavily marketed as such), and I'm concerned that it may have given some potential buyers the impression that all the Level Packs fell a bit short. I am pleased to report that is not the case in the other Level Packs I have played  - the others have each felt like a relatively full experience. It's unfortunate that the BTTF level doesn't have a little more to it.

There are some other gameplay factors to discuss:

  • First - this pack (along with the Doc fun pack) can get you into the BTTF Adventure World. This open-world version of Hill Valley is MUCH more impressive, and has a creative component with time travel that allows you to explore the different versions of Hill Valley from the movies. This makes up for the lacking Level, however if you're on a budget you may be better off just getting Doc, whose Time Train vehicle build has the same time-travel ability as the DeLorean
    • One thing I wondered when the game was first advertised was if they would have some kind of time-travel ability shared between The Doctor and Marty/Doc Brown. Ultimately, that is not the direction they went (the TARDIS has its own abilities and travel device)
  • Second - Michael J. Fox and Christopher Lloyd reprise their roles and lend their voices to their respective characters in the core Dimensions game, the Level Pack, and the Adventure World
    • This is a huge plus for the packs and the game, and a rarity amongst the overall Dimensions content (which features, for many properties, a mix of archive dialogue or voice actors mimicking roles. A few actors reprise, and it's very cool that Fox and Lloyd both come back)
    • When you have both characters on the pad, they each have a custom greeting recorded specifically for each other and the game
  • Third - Marty has very few in-game abilities
    • His guitar provides sonic-smash abilities for breakable glass, and the DeLorean (and its alternate builds) have several key abilities (including the time-travel "treadmill" for lack of a better descriptor), but Marty himself is otherwise pretty lacking
    • Outside of the Adventure World and Level Pack, I rarely have Marty on the toy pad because of this

Overall Opinion

The Back to the Future Level Pack comes in as a mixed-bag, overall. As a fan of BTTF, I found great value just in the Marty minifigure and hoverboard, but when I finally fired up the Level in-game, I found it coming up short.

The Adventure World makes up for the disappointment and the inclusion of Fox and Lloyd is a big plus for longtime fans.

This pack has been on some tremendous discounts lately and it might be time to give it a try if you've been wondering how it comes in. At full retail, it doesn't earn it's value (though none of Dimensions really justifies the list RRP - toys-to-life is an investment), but at the discounts I've been seeing, it's more than worth it.

author: Odeinoichus
title: Gotta Get Back in Time...
review:
Set #71201 Level Pack Back to the Future: Well it’s about time I started discussing this stuff since it’s been a while since I reviewed the Starter Pack. From Series 1, Wave 1 comes this Level Pack, an extra bit of content from the main adventure found within the Starter Pack. The LEGO Cuusoo project already provided us with a Back to the Future set, this expands further on it by including something more for fans of the franchise.

There’s also additional digital content for the LEGO Dimensions game, which I’m certain everybody is well aware of at this point. Anyway, let us discuss this particular set and hopefully it will entice late comers to indulge in some fun adventures in Hill Valley with everybody’s favorite time traveling teen.

Box/Instructions

Box: The packaging for Level Packs features artwork of the in-game universe being introduced. This particular one shows Marty riding his hoverboard while the DeLorean is visible traveling through the gated community’s front entranceway, Lyon Estates that is.

You’ll also find a shot of the main builds on the front and the Minifigure with his Character Tag, the back shows what three builds you can make with the parts of the models and includes imagery of their in-game counterparts. It’s a very uniform design with the colouring and art styles being shared by each of the Level Packs in Series 1 & 2.

Instructions: The paper manual indicates how to put Marty together and then includes information regarding the need to place the figure’s toy tag on the toy pad in order to get the rest of the build instructions. These thin manuals do showcase the rest of the wave typically with checkboxes beside them.

Each manual is the same, minus the choice of character found in either pack. Therefore this will be the only review to discuss the manuals. They are what they are, a bit of a disappointment, but it makes sense to include the rest of the instructions digitally as it allows folks to get more involved with the toy and the game in tandem.

Parts

This set features a limited number of parts and not too many of them are considered rare. The only rare element that has interested folks is the special printed Hoverboard from BttF, Part II.

Minifigure

Marty McFly: This Minifigure is not new, it uses all of the same parts as the figure found in the Cuusoo set, the printing is all the same, the only difference is his accessory which is a red guitar. It’s rather nice to have another chance to get this figure, provided you can still find it at retail, as the DeLorean was discontinued ages ago.

His toy tag features a nice character specific print, which looks quite nice. All-in-all a decent figure included with the set.

The build

DeLorean Time Machine: There are a lot of steps to the builds which results in a lot of simple and easy steps to follow, their problem is that they are all online in the game proper so you have to keep hitting the button to flip through the pages which can cause lag and other problems.

The build however is still really fun as you get to make a miniature looking model of the original DeLorean, it’s a really great build.

Electric Time Machine: In order to unlock this secondary build you need a certain number of gold bricks and studs so that you can unlock features digitally in-game to get the instructions… unless you just look it up online and ignore the digital aspect of the product.

This particular build follows along to the similar steps in the first build, but some of the parts will be moved around and used differently to create a different looking version of the micro-model.

Ultra Time Machine: Again you’ll need to unlock in-game items before you can use these instructions. I will say though this one is a bit of an odd model, the build is meant to make the hovering version of the DeLorean and I don’t believe that this model looks as good as the original once built.

Hoverboard: This build basically uses other parts to give you something to build on top of the Hoverboard piece, otherwise you’d just have the Hoverboard on a Toy Tag, it’s a very flimsy looking build honestly.

Cyclone Board: You modify the Hoverboard build slightly here, but honestly there’s not much to it… I really feel that these builds are extremely unimportant and uninspiring, I think I would have preferred a different choice than the Hoverboard as the second of Marty’s vehicle builds, giving Marty his black pick-up or the 1950’s Doc Brown car he used in the past… admittedly two cars would have been rather boring from a simple build perspective.

Ultimate Hoverjet: Another worthless looking build, honestly I think they should have tried harder to incorporate the hoverboard piece into the actual models and maybe included some interesting and unique micro-builds, for example they could have used the piece for the original Barbie pink model, but then given us Griff’s version using pieces that could build up and actually attach to the Hoverboard instead of making glorified hovering elements with extra parts slap-dashed on.

The completed model

DeLorean Time Machine: This is the best iteration of the model, instead of going through all of them as I did with the builds I’ll discuss everything under one header. The DeLorean’s first model captures the look of the iconic vehicle perfectly. It can be detached from the Toy Tag and roll around on four wheels.

The secondary build changes the outline of the car slightly giving it a slightly altered profile with a hint of it being powered by electricity. It still rolls and can be played with separately from the game, but it doesn’t look as good.

The third build keeps the familiar profile while flipping the tires downward to capture the hovering look of the vehicle. This one won’t roll on its own, but it does still look quite good if a bit goofy because of the four tires sticking out while their axle pieces show off the studs for all to see.

Hoverboard: None of these builds are anywhere near the level that some of the other sets provide, and this is the weakest aspect of this particular set in my eyes that isn’t related to digital content. The need to make a substantial build just hinders everything here, I think I would have preferred it if, instead of using a single piece for the Hoverboard, LEGO designers actually included a fully buildable version of the iconic looking item.

They could have still included the unique looking piece, maybe, but for the in-game models and the play elements of the set, it would have been far more interesting to receive a selection of pink and yellow pieces to make a buildable model which could then be rebuilt into an altered model and Griff’s board with the actual rocket power nozzles for greater mobility. As it stands this particular set of models just failed to realize the potential they could have simply because they stuck to giving us a physical hoverboard piece and then build some stupid unimportant add-on junk that leaves a lot to be desired.

The Digital Content

Character Abilities: Marty is limited, he can perform basic actions in the game like any other character, but the only unique ability listed to him is the Sonar Smash. With his guitar in hand you press the action button and he will break glass LEGO objects.

Vehicles: With the in-game vehicles you can do several things, the first tier of the Time Machine lets you access vehicle accelerator switches and time travel switches. The second form grants a Special Attack, can power Electricity Switches and use the Tow Bar function. The third and final tier for the DeLorean allows you to blow up silver LEGO objects, is a flying vehicle which means it can go into Flying Races and can interact with Flight Docks and Flight Cargo Hooks.

The Hoverboard as is has no special in-game abilities, it’s second tier form once unlocked has access to the Special Attack… I honestly am not sure what the heck that means, probably just means it can shoot. Third tier Hoverboard is a Flying Vehicle that can blow up silver LEGO objects, not really much going for it compared to the DeLorean.

Level & Adventure World: The level for Back to the Future was less substantial than some of the others. Following the story of the first film it was very condensed, focusing on only three key points to the plot and ignoring everything concerning Marty’s parents and the need to get them together. There is a bonus area for the Enchantment Under the Sea Dance, but other than that a lot of the plot is handled in cut scenes and ignores several moments in the film in order to condense and shorten the experience.

Considering the other Level Packs did not do this it’s a real shame that Back to the Future was such a short level.

The Adventure World however makes up a lot more for this, not only do you get to explore 1985 Hill Valley, but Time Treadmills allow you to blast into the past of 1885 and far into the future of 2015, this changes up the look of Hill Valley and its surrounding areas as well. You solve puzzles, unlock new areas to explore by spending studs and address quests from Non-Player Characters that run the gamut of the Cast of all three films.

It’s an expansive world loaded with a lot of charm and fun and the music tracks selected from the actual Movie play in the background allowing you to run all around Hill Valley while Huey Lewis and the News play Power of Love.

I would rate the Level as a five, average, with some fun novelty, but the Adventure World got the lion’s share of the developers attention and it’s a solid 9 out of 10. It would score perfectly if the system could handle everything it needs to, there’s a lot of lag in the digital worlds of LEGO Dimensions and at times things don’t spawn properly, taking a longer time to populate the world with the characters and objects needed to solve the puzzles and succeed in the quests. This could just be the fault of the Playstation 3 and its power capabilities, though considering the size of the game file now that we’ve received all the updates we’re going to get it probably could be just because of that alone.

Overall opinion

LEGO Dimensions began in 2015 and lasted for two years with a lot of in-game content and a lot of Licensed Properties coming together for the first time ever in LEGO form. There were plans for a Year 3 which would have introduced an unknown number of new properties, but LEGO Dimensions was cancelled.

Some blame poor sales on this and I can see where that may have been the case, but honestly LEGO Dimensions was a step up from other Toy’s-To-Life properties. LEGO was innovative like always and featured some very interesting ideas, it was unfortunate that Dimensions was cancelled, but we got a lot of great new elements and ‘sets’ from them.

Case in point this Back to the Future Level Pack, if you enjoy playing LEGO video games and haven’t already gotten into the LEGO Dimensions scene I would suggest getting as much of it as you can before it vanishes completely at retail. This set offers some moderate digital content for the Dimensions video game, it is not the best Level Pack, but it does include some fun little models. The DeLorean Micro Build is the larger draw, the Hoverboard is just a waste of parts on LEGO’s parts.

Recommended.

author: Brick_Connections
title: LEGO Dimensions goes Back to the Future in an Awesome Way!!!
review:
The Back to the Future Level Pack is the first of two packs in the Back to the Future franchise for LEGO Dimensions. This is one of my favourite level packs, and I love the adventure world and the time travel of the both the level and the adventure world. 

Packaging

I've always loved the Dimensions packaging, and this is just as awesome. The DeLorean Time Machine going back in time is a nice touch and a good callback to the main trope of the film.

Minifigure

Marty McFly

There's a Marty McFly minifigure in this pack. It's not exclusive, because the minifigure was released in 21103 The DeLorean Time Machine for LEGO Ideas in 2013, but it is still great to be able to acquire it in another set. The printing on the torso is very detailed and realistic to the source material. The hair is a generic piece. The only new pieces are the printed toy tag with his name and the guitar, which is a nice touch.

Builds

DeLorean Time Machine

The first build in this set is one of the most iconic vehicles in the 1980s, the DeLorean Time Machine. It's very detailed and looks perfect for the scale. The other builds, Electric Time Machine and Ultra Time Machine, resemble the DeLoream from different points in the films. The Electric Time Machine resembles the DeLorean at the end of Back to the Future Part I in 1955 that Marty uses to get back to 1985. The Ultra Time Machine resembles the DeLorean at the beginning of Part II where the DeLorean can now fly. Great Scott, this build is amazing!!

Hoverboard

The second build is a popular trope in Part II, the Hoverboard. The main build is just extra pieces for the rebuilds, with only the actual hoverboard on top. The hoverboard piece is a printed piece and looks just like the film. The rebuilds, Cyclone Board and Ultimate Hoverjet, are just created for the game and have added powers.

Gameplay

Adventure World

This level pack unlocks the Back to the Future Adventure World. (The Doc Brown Fun Pack does the same). I love this adventure world! It looks just like Hill Valley 1985 in the films and has great detailing. There are two other versions of this world if you use time travel spots with the DeLorean to travel to the 1885 version from Part III and the 2015 version from Part II. You can visit the movie theatre in 2015, the courthouse in 1985, and the early town in 1885. 

Minifigure

When you play as Marty McFly, you unlock a new level (more on that later), but only one ability, which brings down his worht a little. His only ability is sonar smash, which he does with his guitar, a call to several scenes with him playing in the films. 

Level

Marty McFly also unlocks a new level, which makes up for the lack of abilities for the minifig. The level takes about 15 minutes to complete, possibly a bit longer if you go for the collectibles, and plays through the entire first film. Lots of elements from the film are removed, like Marty's parents' relationship, Biff, and seeing Hill Valley in 1955. It's a nice short level compared to other levels in the game. 

Vehicles

The DeLorean Time Machine can be used in levels and adventure worlds in certain spots to time travel to the past or future. The Electric Time Machine can do electrical spots, while the Ultra Time Machine can fly. 

The Hoveboard can be used to float across high areas to reach new areas. The rebuilds then act as flying vehicles.

Overall

The set is a reasonable price considering the vehicles' abilities in-game, the minifigure, the level, and the epic adventure world it unlocks. It is pricey in terms of price-per-piece, but is understandable with the theme. Still nice how you can use the figure and builds outside of the core game.

author: HandPositions
title: Where We're Going, We Don't Need Roads
review:
LEGO set #71201 Back to the Future Level Pack is one of the best sets in the LEGO Dimensions theme. At a $30 retail in the year 2015 with only 94 pieces, it may seem extremely overpriced. However, both physically and in the Dimensions game, it is well worth the price. I recently purchased this set off of a Bricklink seller. Not only was it my first Bricklink order, it was also the first retired set I purchased. I have to say it is the best set LEGO Dimensions had to offer.
The set only includes one minifigure, Marty McFly. He is a re - iteration of the character also available in the Ideas DeLorean Time Machine. He has a perfect face, with content and frightened expressions, with a rather standard but well - fitting hair piece. His iconic life vest is printed on his torso, and he has un - printed blue pants. He also includes a guitar element, and can be placed on the included Dimensions toy tag element.
Other builds in this set include the DeLorean Time Machine and Hoverboard. The micro - scale DeLorean is well - built, using smaller but versatile pieces as most Dimensions builds need to in order for it to be converted into three separate models. The main build even allows for the doors to be opened, which I think is a nice touch. It can be converted into Electric and Flying versions of the model using in - game instructions. The Electric car is built well enough with the pieces provided, and the flying build is an excellent inclusion. The Hoverboard build contains an exclusive Hoverboard element, one of the main reasons many fans bought this set. It is built on a rather wacky model, so it can be converted into two other builds. The Hoverboard element is well - built, and allows for a minifigure to stand on it or carry it.
In the game, the character and build unlock numerous bits of content, including a level, adventure world, and different abilities. Since it is called a Level Pack, it was necessary for it to include a level associated with its theme. Since it is a Back to the Future set, the level re - creates main points of the first BTTF film. It begins in Doc Brown's warehouse, where you play as Marty to test the guitar amplifier. After this short scene, it proceeds through the film, travelling back to 1955 using the Time - Travelling ability included with the DeLorean. Although it strays from the plot, making Marty time - travel by choice to warn Doc Brown of the attack, and the level is relatively short, it still captures the film well. The set also unlocks an adventure world, where you can travel through time in Hill Valley to complete restorations, quests, races, and other different challenges. It also includes ways to influence the future by doing things like planting flowers or digging in certain areas that appear in the future.
The Marty McFly character in the game can do various things, such as destroy sonar panels with his guitar. He also says various recorded phrases that correspond with events around him. The Hoverboard build can jump, fly, destroy silver objects, and can even be customized to look different or play sounds. It even stops while hovering over water! The DeLorean build can use time - travel, acceleration switches, electricity, docking ports, and other in - game powers.
Overall, this set was a great addition to my rather small LEGO Dimensions collection. Including three electronically interactive builds, along with the exclusive printed Hoverboard piece, this set is great for any Back to the Future fan or LEGO Dimensions collector.
